Award.AwardTitle: Improving Secondary Organic Aerosol (SOA) Models by Comparison to Chamber and Ambient Data and by Uncertainty and Sensitivity Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will evaluate and compare models that predict the formation of secondary organic aerosol (SOA) in ambient air. SOA are formed in the atmosphere when gas-phase compounds, emitted from human activities and from plants, oxidize and condense into very small particles. These small particles may affect climate, air quality, and atmospheric visibility. Improved modeling of SOA formation will lead to improvements in air quality and climate models.

This research has three primary objectives: (1) to conduct inter-comparisons of different SOA models and test them against atmospheric relevant laboratory measurements and atmospheric measurements; (2) to do a rigorous uncertainty analysis of the models so that the significance of model-measurement differences can be understood; and (3) to perform a comprehensive sensitivity analysis to explore the influential model configurations and/or parameters for the model results of interest, such as aerosol mass and oxygen to carbon ratio. measurements. Several chemical mechanisms of SOA formation will be considered, including an explicit gas-phase inorganic chemistry and the reactions with the SOA precursors, continuous oxidation, gas-to-particle partitioning, and heterogeneous and condensed-phase reactions. Model performance will be evaluated by comparisons with laboratory measurements from the Potential Aerosol Mass (PAM) chambers at both Boston College and the environmental chamber at the California Institute of Technology, and by comparisons with ambient field data collected during the Southern Oxidant & Aerosol Study (SOAS), at a site located in a heavily forested area in Centreville, AL during June and July in 2013.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Each year, poor air quality kills millions of people, mostly when they breathe high levels of aerosol particles. Climate change may make this worse. Alleviating dangerous levels of aerosol particles requires a three-step process: developing models that accurately simulate current aerosol particle amount and composition; using these models to find cost-effective remediation strategies; communicating these results to policy makers who then inform the public and implement the strategies. Improving aerosol models by understanding their uncertainties and sensitivities to model structure and inputs is an important component in this overall remediation strategy.

In this work, we developed a model based on separating different gas-phase and particle-phase chemical components into bins of differing volatility, often called a volatility basis set (VBS). The model then determines the aerosol particle mass concentration and chemical composition by moving the particle-phase chemicals from bin to bin or between the gas and the particle, due to chemical reactions or exchange with the gas phase. This model is essentially the same as models that exist in other universities and government agencies.

The model was run for two experiments conducted in the environmental chamber at CalTech in January 2014. Both involved a chemical commonly emitted by plants, alpha-pinene, but one was with low levels of nitrogen oxides and the other was with high levels. The aerosol particle mass concentration and oxygen-to-carbon ratio (O:C) from the model was compared to the measurements. By running the model thousands of times, the model uncertainty and the sensitivity of the model mass concentration and O:C to the model inputs and structure could be determined. The model sensitivity was determined by three independent methods to find robust results.

For both experiments, the modeled and measured mass concentration and O:C agreed to within combined uncertainties for their evolution over the course of the eight hour length of the experiments. This reasonable agreement contrasts with previous studies in which the modeled aerosol mass concentration was a factor of two to ten lower than the measured aerosol mass concentration.

The model outputs for mass concentration were sensitive to a few factors: the initial O:C ratio; the reaction rate coefficient for the initial reaction of the hydroxyl radical (OH) with the -pinene oxidation products; the particle wall loss; and measured alpha-pinene, OH, temperature. This sensitivity analysis suggests that these model inputs and structure properties should be further investigated. Reducing the uncertainty in these most influential model inputs and structure properties will improve the ability of our model and the many other models that use the volatility basis set concept to simulate atmospheric aerosol particles.
